meta.content: COVID-19 2019-20 School Closing Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) Gov. Northam's order closing Virginia schools through the remainder of the school year creates countless questions for CCPS families and staff members. While we wish we had all the answers right now, the ripples from this deve...

COVID-19 2019-20 School Closing 
Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

Gov. Northam's order closing Virginia schools through the remainder of the school year creates countless questions for CCPS families and staff members. While we wish we had all the answers right now, the ripples from this development require a great deal of new coordination and planning with all stakeholders throughout the school division even while CCPS staff work remotely. This detailed FAQ has answers to many of the questions brought to our attention. However, there are still some issues we're awaiting guidance from the Virginia Department of Education. Thank you to the entire Caroline community for your patience, understanding and hard work as we navigate successfully through these unprecedented Covid-19 waters!


General PK-12 Instructional Information:
What happens to student learning now that schools are closed for the rest of the year? 
The Virginia Department of Education (VDOE) issued guidance on Tuesday, March 24, 2020 to help all school divisions execute plans for continued instruction while ensuring students are served equitably, regardless of income level, access to technology, English learner status or special needs. CCPS is currently developing a variety of delivery methods which may include virtual learning, distribution of activities/resources, additional instruction through summer programming and integration of instruction into coursework next year. More information regarding future instructional requirements will be shared after spring break. In the interim, students should continue to complete the previously distributed paper/online activities (See Continuity of Instruction at www.ccps.us). (Updated 4/15/2020)
Will VDOE cancel Standards of Learning (SOL) testing?
On March 23rd, Governor Northam ordered all K-12 schools in Virginia to close for the remainder of the academic year as a response to the continued spread of COVID-19. As such, the administration of the SOL tests, the local scoring and score entry requirements for the Virginia Alternate Assessment Program, and the administration of the ACCESS for ELs assessment for English Learners are suspended. (Updated 4/15/2/20)

How will my student receive a report card? 
Report Card Distribution (PK-1) and Grades Access (Grades 2-12):
School divisions have been charged with identifying alternate methods of communicating grades to students and families. 
Preschool, Kindergarten, and 1st grade: Students will receive their report card in the mail during the week of April 19. These reports will be mailed.
2nd through 12th grade: Though grades have been accessible for many years using PowerSchool, we recognize that some parents may need a tutorial on how to successfully use this platform. Beginning on Thursday, April 16, 2nd-12th grade parents can access grades electronically through the PowerSchool Parent Portal. Should you need to establish a parent account or simply need support, please find guidance on accessing your child's PowerSchool grades at www.ccps.us. If you have any questions, please reach out to your child's teacher (2-5) or school counselor (6-12). School contact information is linked below:
Bowling Green Elementary: https://www.ccps.us/bes/staff-directory/
Lewis and Clark Elementary: https://www.ccps.us/lces/staff-directory/
Madison Elementary: https://www.ccps.us/mes/staff-directory/
Caroline Middle: https://www.ccps.us/cms/staff-directory/
Caroline High: https://www.ccps.us/chs/staff-directory/
(Updated 4/15/2020) 

Will my student advance to the next grade level? 
All Tier I students (students passing classes at the end of the third quarter will advance to the next grade level. Tier II students (students who are failing classes) are pending advancement to the next grade or course upon completion and submission on Phase I-III lessons. For more information refer to the Continuity of Instruction plan at: https://www.ccps.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/CCPS20-COI-Plan-FINAL-v3.pdf. You may also contact your childs teacher.

Will CCPS hold summer school? 
Any decision to reopen CCPS facilities will be made in consultation with health officials and will prioritize the safety of students, staff members and our community. Options pertaining to summer school will be communicated in the future. (Updated 4/15/2020)

If our family/student has a question, who can we contact during the length of the closure? 
If your family/student has a question during the COVID-19 school closure, please reach out by email to your building level principal, individual teacher(s) or school counselor who will be able to assist you. (Updated 4/15/2020)

BGES- Cynthia Heckstall checkstall@ccps.us
LCES-Cyndi Brown cbrown@ccps.us
MES- Teresa Hicks thicks@ccps.us
CMS- Darin Thompson dathompson@ccps.us
CHS- Josh Just jjust@ccps.us

Director of Elementary- Terrie Haley thaley@ccps.us
Director of Secondary- Karen Foster kfoster@ccps.us
Director of Special Education- Lora Glass lglass@ccps.us
Assistant Superintendent- Dr. Herb Monroe hmonroe@ccps.us
Food Services- Keith Conner kconner@ccps.us

Class of 2020 Information:
 What are the requirements for seniors scheduled to graduate in 2020?
Dr. Lane, State Superintendent of Instruction, has provided as much flexibility allowable by the Code of Virginia for those students graduating with the 2019-2020 cohort. The following graduation requirements can be waived based on authority granted to the Superintendent of Public Instruction per Executive Order Fifty-One (2020):
Students currently enrolled (as of March 13) in a course for which they need a standard or verified credit in order to graduate;
Students who have successfully completed a course required for graduation, but have not earned the associated verified credit;
Students who have not completed the student-selected test;
 Students who are currently enrolled in or have previously completed a course leading to a CTE credential necessary for a Standard Diploma but have not yet earned the credential;
Students who have not completed a United States and Virginia history course*;
Students who have not completed a fine or performing arts or career and technical education course*;
Students in the second of sequential courses*;
Students who have not completed an economics and personal finance course*.

*Some credit-based graduation requirements are still provided for in the Code of Virginia. While these cannot be waived outright, these can be addressed by providing new instruction and pursuing alternate pathways to the 140-clock-hour requirement based on revised Board of Education guidelines. 
The following graduation requirements will require action by the General Assembly in order to be waived. We will monitor the waiver process when the GA reconvenes in April. Should alternate arrangements be necessary, CCPS will work with the impacted students to support completion of the requirement(s): 
Students who have not completed training in emergency first aid, cardiopulmonary resuscitation, and the use of automated external defibrillators, including hands-on practice of the skills necessary to perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation; and
Students who have not completed a virtual course
Students enrolled in cosmetology or master barber courses will be eligible to take the licensure examination if their instructor submits a Training Verification form certifying the student completed the VDOE-required training, regardless of the hour amount. 
(Updated 4/15/2020)

How will we celebrate our seniors?
CCPS and CHS are dedicated to honoring our twelfth graders with traditional senior rites of passage such as prom and graduation. While we continue to monitor national, state, and local public gathering ordinances, teams of CHS educators are creating various celebratory options that will be readily implemented upon the lifting of the public health safety measures. Stay tuned - more information will be shared! (Updated 4/15/20)

Special Education Information:
Is a school required to continue to provide FAPE to students with disabilities during the COVID-19 school closure?

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":8156,"s":"The IDEA, Section 504, and Title II of the ADA do not specifically address a situation in which elementary and secondary schools are closed for an extended period of time (generally more than 10 consecutive days) because of exceptional circumstances, such as an outbreak of a particular disease. If a Local Education Agency (LEA) closes its schools to slow or stop the spread of COVID-19, and does not provide any educational services to the general student population, then a LEA would not be required to provide services to students with disabilities during that same period of time. 
During Phase 3 of the Continuity of Instruction plans, CCPS will make every effort to provide special education and related services to students in accordance with the childs IEP or 504 plan. There may be exceptional circumstances that could affect how a particular service is provided. Case managers and therapists will be coordinating their efforts to support students instructionally.
(Updated 4/10/2020)

How can students collect assistive technology equipment and devices? How will AT equipment be returned at the end of the school year?
Students in need of assistive technology should coordinate this request with their case manager. AT is available for distribution. We want to ensure practices are in place to support the health and wellbeing of Caroline County students, families and staff. Therefore, requests to check out equipment will be coordinated on an individual basis. 

A process and date for collection of all AT equipment will be established for the end of the school year. (Updated 4/10/2020)

Are community resources available to support students with disabilities?
Yes, community resources are available to support our students while they are learning at home.
Beginning Thursday, April 16 from 12-1:00 and continuing weekly, VCU- ACE will provide an opportunity for parents to join us for Lunch and Learn. An interactive and secure Zoom meeting that will address different topics each week. There will be a short presentation with time for Q&A. Zoom Information: https://vcu.zoom.us/j/981818226?pwd=OXVuWXJidUJFbUxYcWI1emNGcDFOQT09 Call in Number: US: +1 312 626 6799 Meeting ID: 981 818 226 -- Password: 032586 
The Virginia Department of Education offers suggestions for parents and families to support learning at home in the resource, COVID-19: A Parent Guide for School-Aged Children.
VA TV Classroom on-air schedule is as follows:
K-3 instruction airs from 1-2 p.m. with Standards of Learning-aligned content provided by WHRO Public Media. Learn to Grow with WHRO segments will be 15 minutes in length and led by teachers. 
Grades 7-10 instruction airs from 2-3 p.m. with SOL-aligned content provided by WHRO Public Media focusing on Earth Science and Algebra 1.
VA TV Classroom can be seen throughout the commonwealth on the WHRO and VPM channels.
	(Updated 4/10/2020)

How will CCPS receive referrals to special education during the closure period? 
Parents have the flexibility to make referrals to special education now or wait until school resumes. Referrals may be submitted via email, mail or phone call. Because school buildings are closed, mail may not be received on a daily basis. As always, CCPS will be flexible in allowing parents to attend meetings by alternative means. (Updated 3/25/2020)
How will special education evaluations and IEP/504 meetings be completed during the closure? 
The Office of Civil Rights (OCR) has provided guidance that IEP teams are not required to meet in person while schools are closed. In addition, OCR has stated that If an evaluation of a student with a disability requires a face-to-face assessment or observation, the evaluation would need to be delayed until school reopens. Evaluations and reevaluations that do not require face-to-face assessments or observations may take place while schools are closed, so long as a students parent or legal guardian consents. These same principles apply to a student with a disability who has a plan developed under Section 504, or who is being evaluated under Section 504.

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":12268,"s":"CCPS will continue to provide guidance to IEP/504 teams on how to maintain timelines and to document clearly if a delay occurs, the nature and extent of the delay and the plan to move as quickly as possible to prevent any further delay. In addition, amendments to IEPs do not require a face-to-face meeting and may be conducted virtually or by telephone. 
As always, CCPS will be flexible in the use of alternative means to support parents' ability to attend IEP/504 meetings. Additionally, CCPS will document all attempts to arrange meetings with parents, including providing meeting notice that complies with special education regulations. (Updated 3/25/2020)
My child is in need of mental health and emotional health services. Are services available in our community during the stay-at-home order?
Yes, resources are available. Caroline County Public Schools has a list of Social Emotional Learning Resources available on our website. Additionally, the Rappahannock Area Community Services Board supports our families. RACSB continues to accept referrals for case management, outpatient and psychiatric services. If families or partner agencies have a child or family in need of mental health services, reach out to the Caroline county clinic directly at 804-633-9997. Emergency Services staff are available 24 hours a day and can be reached at 540-373-6876. (Updated 4/15/20) 
How will homebound and home-based services be provided?
We are taking precautions to provide for the health and safety of staff and students to prevent the spread of COVID-19. While schools are closed, homebound/home-based instruction will not be provided in a face-to-face setting. Students currently receiving approved homebound or home-based instruction will be able to receive instruction through the instructional resources provided on the CCPS website or through paper copies of lessons available from each school. If you have concerns about specific assignments, please reach out to your childs homebound teacher or classroom teacher via email. If you have questions about homebound instruction in general, the HB Coordinator can be reached at sgayle@ccps.us. (Updated 4/12/2020)
 

Elementary Teaching & Learning Information:
How will PreK and K registration for the 2020-2021 school year be impacted by the COVID-19 closure? 

CCPS will open kindergarten enrollment on April 16th. Due to the COVID-19 guidelines, we have adopted a process that will allow parents to either access an enrollment packet on the CCPS website (ccps.us) or pick up a packet at any of the elementary school food distribution sites on Monday, Wednesday or Friday between the hours of 9:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m. Once completed, you may email the enrollment packet to the school registrar or drop off at your schools food distribution site. This is a conditional process, therefore, document verification and student screenings will occur at a later date.

In addition, CCPS will continue with the preschool recruitment via phone. If you have already submitted a Pre-Application, you will not need to do anything further. If your child is eligible, the school registrar will contact you to continue with the process.

If you have not completed a Pre-Application, you can either access it on the CCPS website (ccps.us) or you can pick up a Pre-Application at any of the elementary school food distribution sites on Monday, Wednesday or Friday between the hours of 9:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m. Once completed, email the form to Calandra Simms at csimms@ccps.us or drop off at your schools food distribution site. If your child is eligible, the registrar will contact you to continue the application process. This is a conditional process, therefore, document verification and student screenings will occur at a later date to determine final acceptance of students.

School Registrars:
Bowling Green Elementary: Carrie Moser: cmoser@ccps.us
Lewis and Clark Elementary: Brenda Hackett: bhackett@ccps.us
Madison Elementary: Cindy St. Clair: cstclair@ccps.us

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":16288,"s":"(Updated 4/14/2020)


Secondary Teaching & Learning Information
How can my student get his/her Chromebook repaired during the closure?
Students may put in helpdesk tickets as usual to Technology Services for issues with their CCPS Chromebooks. CMS Students should send requests to cmshelp@ccps.us. CHS students should send requests to chshelp@ccps.us. A drop-off and pick-up process will be set up as needed to accommodate all received tickets. (3/25/2020)
How will students turn in their Chromebooks at the end of the school (May 20, 2020)?
A CMS/CHS Chromebook collection process has been identified; however, the implementation timeline is dependent upon resolution of the COVID-19 crisis. Additional information regarding device collection will be communicated in the future. (Updated 3/25/2020)	
How will my students turn in uniforms, library books, etc?
Collection dates will be forthcoming with a date to be determined in May. Specific communication will be provided closer to May. (Updated 4/15/2020)
Do students still continue Virtual VA (VVA) courses?
Yes, students enrolled in VVA courses should resume all coursework on Monday, March 30. At that time students should remain in contact with VVA teachers via phone, email, learning management system (LMS), or web conferencing throughout the extended school closure. VVA faculty will continue to teach, conduct live online instructional sessions with students, and remain available to parents, counselors, mentors, and students for the duration of the 20192020 school year. (Updated 3/25/2020)
How will students enrolled in Dual Enrollment(DE) or Advanced Placement(AP) continue their learning?
Students enrolled in DE classes with Germanna will continue to work on assignments using Schoology as the learning platform. Students enrolled in AP classes will continue to receive continuity of instruction plans from Caroline High School teachers. (Updated 3/25/2020)
How will CCPS communicate AP testing information with parents and students?
Communication regarding changes to the 19-20 Advanced Placement test administration is being sent directly from the College Board and CHS administration to parents and registered students. Information shared in these communications is summarized below:
Traditional face-to-face exam administrations will not take place. 
For the 201920 exam administration only, students can take a 45-minute online exam at home.
Students will be able to take these streamlined exams on any device they have access tocomputer, tablet, or smartphone. Taking a photo of handwritten work will also be an option. 
For each AP subject, there will be 2 different testing dates.
The full exam schedule, specific free-response question types that will be on each AP Exam, and additional testing details were made available on April 3.
College Board is offering new Daily Online Review AP Classes beginning March 25th. The free, live AP review lessons, will be delivered by AP teachers from across the country. The classes can be accessed from the AP YouTube channel (youtube.com/advanced placement) and will also be available on-demand. These optional, mobile-friendly classes are not dependent on current AP teachers continuing instruction. The lessons will focus on reviewing the skills and concepts from the first 75% of the course. There will also be some supplementary lessons covering the final 25% of the course.
The College Board recognizes that the digital divide could prevent some low-income and rural students from participating. Working with partners, they will invest so that these students have the tools and connectivity they need to review AP content online and take the exam. If your students need mobile tools or connectivity, you can reach out to them directly to let them know. 
For more information, please visit the AP Updates for Schools Impacted by Coronavirus* website.(Updated 4/15/2020)

DOCS_modelChunk = [{"ty":"is","ibi":20348,"s":"Phase I & II ran from March 18-April 24. Students are to submit a total of 4 activities per course/subject for Phases I and II (one activity per week per course/subject). All activities must be submitted on 4/22 or 4/24 by email, hard copy at your childs school or via Schoology (option for 6th-12th). 
The third and final phase of the Continuity of Learning plan, Phase III, will begin on April 	 and run through May 15. Students meeting Tier I attributes, may elect to complete Phase III activities aimed at enhancing students readiness for a successful 2020-21 school year. Instructional materials will be available online, on Schoology (6-12), or for pick up at your childs school from 8am-1pm on Wednesday, 4/22 and Friday, 4/24. If your student requires Tier II learning assignments as outlined in the Continuity of Instruction Plan, he/she will receive individualized instructional materials directly from the classroom teacher. Tier II (Phase III) activities will be due by 5/15. 
Should you have any student-specific questions or general inquiries related to Phase II or III learning, please use the communication methods outlined on the last page of the Continuity of Instruction document Continuity of Instruction Plan. (Updated 4/15/2020)

How will CCPS handle reimbursement of field trips or other monies?
CCPS is investigating options for field trips and other refunds. Further information will be provided in a future communication. (4/20/2020)

How will students be able to access meals while schools are closed for the rest of the school year? Grab & Go Meals are available for pickup, Monday, Wednesday and Friday at the following locations: 
School Sites: BGES, LCES, MES, CMS (9:30a.m.-12:30p.m.)
Community Stops:
Caroline County Visitor Center (Carmel Church, 9:30a.m.-12:30p.m.)
Port Royal Town Hall, (Port Royal, 9:30a.m.-12:30p.m.)
Second Mount Zion Baptist Church (Dawn, 9:30a.m.-12:30p.m.)
Upper Caroline Fire Department (Woodlawn, 9:30a.m.-10:30a.m.)
Times and Sites/Stops may change as we monitor the usage of each site and will be updated when changes are made. (Updated 4/15/2020)
How can CCPS support families with no Internet access?
All Continuity of Instruction materials are designed to be accessible in printed format. Parents should contact their child's school to obtain copies of any needed Continuity of Instruction materials. (Updated 4/15/2020)

A number of families have ordered group/class pictures, spirit wear, and/or fundraiser items that need to be picked up from schools. How and when will families that paid receive them? 
The current public health crisis requires stringent measures to be implemented to minimize exposure and acceleration of virus spread. As a result, our ability to distribute these items is diminished. We will continue to monitor the COVID-19 developments and communicate distribution plans when staff and community health will not be compromised by these events.
